Projects.ProjectTopic: Spatial rendering, Design exploration, VR user experience, Metaverse
Projects.ProjectMyRole: The metaverse subject matter expert, In charge of building and executing the Research Routine and rapid VR prototyping
Projects.TeamComposition:
2 experience designers, 
2 Strategic designers, 
2 Venture architects
Projects.ImpactContentLis:
The project was the first ever sold metaverse project for the firm. 

With our strategic input, our client made significant progress on building their own metaverse strategy.

We've had two major pivot during the period of my staffing.
The first phase was to explore the VR use case for the family and business setting. The second phase was to explore the feasibility of building VR based virtual community within our client's core social group (Employees and family).The third use case builds on top of the second phase result. We validated the use case to extend the virtual community concept with a VR onboarding experience for new joiners of our client's community. 

The project extended from originally a 7 weeks project to a project lasting more than an year. It is still an on going project as of now (OCT 2023.)

SummaryContentList.ContentText: Our client is a state-owned investment entity in GSA. The client have no prior knowledge in the field of metaverse, spatial rendering and digital marketing. I was the metaverse subject matter expert of this project in charge of the research routines and the prototype strategy and the production lead of the case

The team treated the project as a traditional digital design project at the start. We then learned that VR uses cases are vastly different from usual digital design cases and we had to pivot. Most of our work would rely on pivoting digital design methodology as we uncover the potential of VR technology.
How might we help our client, locate in a remote location, to better connect with each other and their loved ones?

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Rigorous research needed to learn about VR
SummaryContentList.SubtitleText: 15 expert interviews, 40 in person VR prototyping session, 200 response in quantitative research
SummaryContentList.ContentText: VR the and immersive tech is a entirely unknown territory for the firm. The team had come to the consensus that we would need rigorous research to document evidence that advocates a business use case

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Our client wants to attract young talents
SummaryContentList.ContentText: Our client needs to be in the proximity of great young talents according to their growth plan for the coming decade. The young population within various online VR community has great affinity to experimental tech and they are exactly the group our client wants to attract.

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Articulating business value of immersion tech
SummaryContentList.ContentText: Our team made the initial hypothesis that a VR product could indeed bring the client's community together, while helping them attract young talents in various digital communities networks. We used guerrilla tactics to validate the hypothesis before we head into the build

SummaryContentList.SubtitleText: 4 rooms built, 1 as testing environment and 2 delivered to client
SummaryContentList.ContentText: The VR rooms have been tested that foster great interaction and conversation within their community
The room was used for testing and user interview purposes. We learned about the usage of props, digital identities and how such space could afford genuine interaction.
This a room built for social interactions. The key goal of these room is to have various props for users

SummaryContentList.SubtitleText: Positive user experience spotted during passive user studies.
SummaryContentList.ContentText:
The pillow fort was a resounding success that surprised many senior stake holders. 

The objects were fairly simple: motionless pillows you can drag and place. Despite its simplicity, this the place where we spot creativity being unleash as most of the participants enjoys shaping the pillows into different forms while they have plenty of genuine conversation.
Other objects built for simple interactions also received positive feedback including interactive fondue pots, cinema, interactive fireplace, football arena and fireworks

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Pivoting from failure: The Onboarding Room
SummaryContentList.ContentText: The room was built in just 5 working days leveraging all the previous assets we procured. The room was available for our clients to onboard their new starters

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Capturing the look and feel as forms provides functions
SummaryContentList.ContentText: Different from the usual 2D digital design, the look and feel itself should be regard as a feature too and this was accidentally overlooked.

ChallengeContent.STARTitle: Find a way to execute design exploration in a industry with no quick and dirty prototyping tools
ChallengeContent.ChallengeSummary: The VR design is new to the modern UX process. Most of the work is done following the gaming industry pattern. Tools like figma does not yet exist on the platform. It is up to the designer to set up their environment to find the right solution to uncover the value VR is going to be able to bring
ChallengeContent.SituationTitle: Lacking tools with rapid prototyping capabilities
ChallengeContent.SituationContent:
Design with VR would need a very different approach from the traditional UI/UX point of view. This is uncharted territory for both the firm and our client. 

•  No rapid prototyping tools. The time it takes to test a concept is significantly longer comparing to the traditional UI/UX 2D digital project.
•  The project has a short time span initially. we need to put together a convince use case that would help our client's business in a short 7 weeks sprint.
ChallengeContent.TaskTitle: Creating VR use case hypothesis with a plan to validate it
ChallengeContent.TaskContent:
Initially, the team was planning to leverage external vendor to build VR prototypes for validation. The task was given as follows: 

•  Define methods to build VR prototypes 
•  Define the research routines to extract insights. 
•  Communicate the initial hypothesis with the prototype built by external vendor
ChallengeContent.ActionTitle: Defining a rapid prototyping routine that currently does not exist in the industry
ChallengeContent.ActionContent:
The VR prototype which the external vendor offers were far from ideal. The team is struggling to achieve consistent output for the look and feel and the functions for the VR prototype 

I decided to take the lead and pivot the testing methodologies with new tools and a more agile approach: 

•  Embracing the principal of 'seeing is believing'. Setting up the guiding principal that the only way to deliver meaningful insight is to put VR product in front of our testing participants. 
•  Utilised VR mock ups to validate our hypothesis in demo sessions with the client senior stakeholders and through user research with a captive user group picked by the client side. 
•  Key Pivot: Leading the team to Use the 'VRChat' to build quick and dirty VR experiences to test and gather insights, with extremely basic unity build. At time, we focused on simple script, look and feel, and design articulation.

 Leveraging my experience in Spatial rendering, we built 4 different VR scenes to explore the potential VR value with our client.
ChallengeContent.ResultTitle: Organic approach help us land the VR proposition exactly where they need to be
ChallengeContent.ResultContent:
•  The level of flexibility was welcoming. The design team were able to coop with the need to rapidly change the direction of the project. 
•  We were able to rapidly reflect the user feedback onto the VR scenario similar to the agile design process

ChallengeContent.STARTitle: Explain the business value of immersive tech and digital community to non-digital-first client and colleagues
ChallengeContent.ChallengeSummary: After rounds of testing and design exploration, it is now up to us to translate the findings into actions for our client. The firm had many different frameworks to frame the business issues and provide solutions. However, in our case, we have to proceed with out those existing materials as the firm is lacking talent and proper research in this topic prior to this project.
ChallengeContent.SituationTitle: VR business strategy from scratch and no prior research from the firm
ChallengeContent.SituationContent:
•  Lack of support from the rest of the firm as this is considered to be a new territory for the firm
•  Team consists of experienced tech consultants, but no prior experience in VR, spatial rendering, digital community and gaming.
•  Ambiguous VR use cases through desk research making it hard for the team to align on the ideal proposition. 

Our team needs to explore the VR use cases and uncover the Business value it could bring to our client. 

This section is mostly about the general VR strategy planning
ChallengeContent.TaskTitle: Pioneer the process for both the firm and the client by giving input on the metaverse matter
ChallengeContent.TaskContent:
Initially, we were expected to explore the VR use cases in both the family setting and the business setting with our client. we were tasked to explore VR product values in these space for our clients. 

Our task:
•  Put together VR use cases and potential business value from research findings
•  Make the strategy planning to help our client solve the problem they are facing (Isolation) and drive growth for the future expansion of their organisation
ChallengeContent.ActionTitle: Source real world VR aficionados to co-create our VR strategy for our client
ChallengeContent.ActionContent:
At the later stage of the projcet, it was evident that the captive user group from our client was not going ot be able to provide us enough insight to reflect the broader growth potential in VR as our client gets increasingly excited about the VR communities.

After refinement, we have name the settings as 'the digital community use case', and 'the workroom use case' to be more precise on the value we want to bring. 

 I than acquired the resource from the project leader to:

•  Leverage my proximity to the current VR aficionados (VRChat and other metaverse titles) for recruitment and invite them to explore potential VR use case for our clients. 
•  Hosting open demo session for wider audience from different age group and gaming habits to collect their input on our VR use case
ChallengeContent.ResultTitle: A solid VR use case that unblocks our client's geolocational limits
ChallengeContent.ResultContent:
We find that: 
•  The aspect of VR communities currently present in apps such as VRChat could bring younger population to the proximity of our client's digital marketing effort. This is crucial to our client's long term goal for growth. 
•  VR product is exceptionally effective for our client's isolated community in remote regions to connect with their loved ones. Especially connecting with young ones who we predicted to be the main VR users in the coming years.

Main concern was:
•  VR lacks the wide scale adaptation when comparing with the current mobile apps.
•  Custom VR product build are extremely pricey.

Although being one of the digital delivery method. It is less cost effective in growth potential when comparing with other digital channels.

ChallengeContent.STARTitle: Requested to build interactive VR prototype in 7 days
ChallengeContent.ChallengeSummary: Building VR scene is a short amount of time is difficult. As the rest of the team is occupied, I will have to pivot and build a scene that communicates our hypothesis of the VR use case to the client in just 7 days
ChallengeContent.SituationContent:
Partnered VR studio delivered unsatisfactory result for VR demo session. The firm team needs to come up with alternatives in short amount of time for client presentation.

The main reasons for suboptimal delivery are:
•  The team collectively overlooked the look and feel the client was looking for. The result of the VR scene is simply too much like 'video game'
•  The complicated, linear progression of the demo contradicts some of explorative nature of the VR environment. The usability is not at a satisfactory level.
ChallengeContent.TaskTitle: Build the VR scene under time pressure
ChallengeContent.TaskContent:
The team was tasked to:
•  Replace the VR scene produced by the partnered studio in just 1.5 weeks.
•  Test and optimise the environment, making sure it is ready to host the VR demo session for visitors.
ChallengeContent.ActionTitle: Simple level design but more focused on capturing the look and feel and easy interactions
ChallengeContent.ActionContent:
With the result from the research sessions, I convinced the design team that the key for a successful VR build should be the explorative interactions with objects and other users instead of heavily scripted events. 

As such, I begin the design of the new VR scene with:
•  Simple level design starting with interior design floor plan instead of game level design to capture the spatial experience most users are used to (Instead of surreal gaming vibes).
•  Utilising assets built previously. Production is mostly just the placement of the objects with special focus on achieving the artistic direction.
•  All items designed with interaction (sitting, mirror, pool table) built in, plus simple activities leveraging VRChat's physic engine (tennis, volleyball).
ChallengeContent.ResultTitle: Alignment with the client. Successfully materialised the essence of a VR use case
ChallengeContent.ResultContent:
•  A mock up VR experience that successfully communicated the proposed VR value in just 1.5 weeks. 
•  Received positive feedback from senior stakeholders and clients.
•  VR space is used for client's future employee onboarding project. 

Our goal for design is to have the users to define the space with careful articulation of the object's affordance.

Projects.ProjectTopic: User experience design, Full stack digital design, User research, Cross functional team, Agile development
Projects.ProjectMyRole: Leading the workstream design process. Collaborating on product planning. Acting scram master

SummaryContentList.ContentText: Our client's operation requires a lot of manual tasks. Without validation, the manual tasks are causing a large margin of error damaging their reputation with increases the cost to their operation

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Facilitating brain-storming workshops to problem-solve collectively
SummaryContentList.SubtitleText: 8 work session with clients, 3 major collaborative workshop to problem solve
SummaryContentList.ContentText: The client's operation was extremely complex. It was agreed that the quickest way to build our hypothesis is by collaborating with our clients. We had 3 major problem solving sessions and 8 work sessions to further iron out the details.

SummaryContentList.TitleText: Fostering the agile development set up
SummaryContentList.ContentText: Due to the staffing constrains, we have no product managers familiar with the agile process on the case. Designers on this case were the expert closest to the agile framework. I was tasked to build the agile development framework for my workstream.

Upon learning about the client's operation. We identified that the key issue was the amount of mental calculation involved in the operation causing all of the issues mentioned above. Our hypothesis is that a well built interface for users to interact with data would be the solution.
Task overview to see the remaining tasks
Inviting clients to contribute to the wireframing effort. Non-designers could also have fun!
Help centre to provide contextual assistance
Navigation rework to reflect the user sessions feedback
Carefully crafted panel to include all information in one screen without jumping back and forth.

SummaryContentList.TitleText: User research sessions to validate our deliverables
SummaryContentList.SubtitleText: 4 user research sessions with over 20 participants
SummaryContentList.ContentText: The result from the user research sessions was resoundingly positive. the users were affirmative that the product we built will solve the issues they are facing. The sessions was documented and sent to the client for future upskilling programme.

ImpactContentList.ContentText: Our client is a major international non-profit organisation aiming to further digitise their operation for scale. We need to build a digital journey from the ground up. Demolishing undesirable process and create the new link in their operation.

nThis is a behemoth piece of work, we separate the work into many different streams. I work closely with the client team manager, the BCG engineering team, and a BCG business analyst for this work stream. I am responsible for the workstream's design operation.

ChallengeContent.STARTitle: Problem solving an outdated digital operation that is prone to human error
ChallengeContent.ChallengeSummary: Documenting the problem solving skills in a modern agile development environment plus showcasing the UX design progress powered by collaborative sessions
ChallengeContent.SituationTitle: Unscalable process prone to human error that costs our client dearly.
ChallengeContent.SituationContent:
•  The client's operation is prone to human errors due to the lacking of proper data validation.
•  Manual process makes the operation hard to scale. This is problematic in the face of rising demand to their service.
ChallengeContent.TaskTitle: Build the digital product with scalability in mind
ChallengeContent.TaskContent:
•  Investigate the reason why the as-is journey is prone to error. 
•  Fixing the operation that is mostly Excel-based with a digital product that has data validation at every step. 
•  Ensure that the product future proof and is easy to scale.
ChallengeContent.ActionTitle: Investigating the journey, connecting the dots, then figure out what we can automate. With a strict lean MVP mindset
ChallengeContent.ActionContent:
•  Hosting collaborative design session to extract insights from the clients and users and turn their ideas into design to speed up our process tremendously.
•  Creating collaborative design platform to collate the design insight across the client team. First draft of the design journey were done in just three days.
•  Investigate the blockers to the scalability. Create and iterate the product strategy for the problem solving
ChallengeContent.ResultTitle: Connected team align on the focus of the development after the first sprint cycle
ChallengeContent.ResultContent:
•  Successfully identified the core feature with the utmost priority to build in sprint one with no prior research. 
•  Setting up abd maintained the platform for continuous collaboration on multiple boards

ParagraphContentList.ContentText: Co- working session and the effort to document the team's output
Initial site map for alignment. Phased out after roadmap on Azure was more tangible to assess the build effort
Product blueprint, marking the main five building blocks for prioritisation

ChallengeContent.STARTitle: Working with a team with zero experience in agile environment
ChallengeContent.ChallengeSummary: Making most of the situation with the staffing constrains. Taking the team unto the journey of agile product development
ChallengeContent.SituationTitle: Conflicting interests in product development roles while setting up agile development environment
ChallengeContent.SituationContent:
•  Working with an organisation new to the product development environment. 
•  Working with product manager with no prior experience in digital development. Upskilling is part of the internal brief. It was not a usual product development set up and can cause conflicting interest. 
•  As senior design project leaders realise that we need to push for better understanding of agile development in the team, they proposed an one off agile workshop and expect the rest of the team to take the helm to guide the agile process.
ChallengeContent.TaskTitle: Taking the team onto the journey of agile ways of working
ChallengeContent.TaskContent:
•  The senior project leader expect the designers, who are the most likely personal on the project with the best knowledge to agile development, to help the team understand agile development and its value. 
•  Working with the understaffed situation. Be extra lean with the development progress.
ChallengeContent.ActionTitle: Ownership of the agile rituals from day one. Acting as scram master until the client is comfortable to assume the role
ChallengeContent.ActionContent:
1. Building the agile development
•  Taking ownership of the design rituals on day one. 
•  Assume the role of scram master, setting up the system of documenting development effort. 
2. Inviting the client to assume the product owner's role with baby steps
•  Commit to give them full visibility on the teams' capacity from the start to let the client manager understand the process. 
•  Communicating the risk of unrealistic product development goals when there needs to be deprioritised.
•  Make an example by executing the agile rituals, then invite the client to assume the roles afterward. 
•  Sidestepping the agile lead role, then have the client assume the responsibility as we give our continuous support on communicating with investors and senior executive members of the organisation. 
3. Explaining how and why we do product iterations. Bringing the zero to one MVP building experience to the project.
4. Actively involve in product planning to set up the scope of the development and validate workplan to make sure we have a realistic timeline to deliver the product
ChallengeContent.ResultTitle: Good teaming performance from a quantifiable source
ChallengeContent.ResultContent:
•  The workstream is deemed as the most efficient team across the entire project base on the internal firm teaming survey. 
•  The team members are happy with the level of exposure to the agile ways of working and would love to take on ownership on agile rituals voluntarily.
•  The client team's project manager was able to handle the operation of the team at the later half of the project. 
•  With my active participation in product planning. The team cut the time need to build the product from four product iteration(32 weeks, 16 sprints) in to just three product iterations (24 weeks, 12 sprints).

ChallengeContent.STARTitle: Building and shipping the web app with suboptimal design system and lack of resources
ChallengeContent.ChallengeSummary: Executing product building tasks with agile and UCD methodologies. Saving time and achieving the development goal with precision
ChallengeContent.SituationTitle: Designing with a almost non-existent digital branding guideline with tight deadlines
ChallengeContent.SituationContent:
•  The client's design system is a web page based colour palette. With no functional semantic colours guidelines
•  All digital related progress is not being defined. 
•  The design system is a duplicated MUI library without a digital specific branding.
ChallengeContent.TaskTitle: Deliver a fully working product for the project duration
ChallengeContent.TaskContent:
•  Build the product with the suboptimal design system
•  Test the product to validate our work in terms of usability. 
•  Reach the KPIs of the workstream for the product we build.
ChallengeContent.ActionTitle: Setting up routines to iterate the digital branding
ChallengeContent.ActionContent:
•  Small incremental changes to the design system while we design the product allowing us to churn out screens for testing as we improves the design system
•  As design stream lead, take ownership of the research session and synthesise the result for Case team share back. 
•  Active QA session between the development team to ensure the quality of the end product and implement change if needed.
ChallengeContent.ResultTitle: A functional product built in just 3 months with necessary validations
ChallengeContent.ResultContent:
•  Successfully cutting down 40% of time needed to complete the client's operation cycle which meets the strategic KPI set at the start of the project(Data from final user testing). 
•  Extremely positive rating on all user sessions (In total 6 was held). The product has good usability and testing participants (future end users) are happy with the features and are affirmative that this is going to improve their operation. 
•  Robust data validation at every single stage of the operation.
